discussion.content:
Restrictions for Management Frame Protection
â€¢ Lightweight access points support infrastructure MFP in local and monitor modes and in FlexConnect
mode when the access point is connected to a controller. They support client MFPin local,FlexConnect,
and bridge modes.

questions.question_text: Which two access point modes support infrastructure MFP? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Local EAP is used with Flex connect (H REAP) mode to offer a backup solution for client authentication when the AP loses it's link to the external RADIUS server, or if one is not configured. When falling back to local mode, it can use local mode (internal) or a locally present LDAP server.

questions.question_text: Which two methods of authentication are available for Local EAP?

discussion.content: 802.11b uses the transmission type DSSS, which uses a channel width of 22mhz. OFDM uses a channel width of 20mhz.

questions.question_text: What is the channel width of an 802.11b wireless channel?

discussion.content:
Bridge mode can operate as a bridge only for access points, which would not directly serve clients. Bridge mode can also be used to form a partial or full mesh AP network, which would directly serve clients. 

Monitor mode does not transmit, only receives and reports, similar to Sniffer mode.

questions.question_text: Which three access point modes service clients? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
B is not the best choice because reflection is a concern with very dense materials like metal.
Wood will absorb much of the signal so A is correct. The signal passing through a forest would also cause scattering since there are many objects in the way of the signal, so D is the other correct answer.

comments.content: Agreed, Scattering is reflection of waves due to humidity, dust etc not really from physical objects.

questions.question_text: Which two principles must be considered when deploying a wireless network through a wooded area? (Choose two.)
